Notes on affinities: The anatomy of the specimens suggest affinities with the Blechnaceae (sensu Kramer et al., 1990a) and the Dryopteridaceae (sensu Kramer et al., 1990b)
Type locality: 8 km from Aluminé City, Neuquen Province
Organs: Stems, frond bases, adventitious roots, crozier fragments
Collection: Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales “Bernardino R. Rivadavia”, División Paleobotánica

Notes on age: Bomfleur_etal-2016 also supports incertae sedis, as there is insufficient evidence to assign the fossil to Osmundales
Type locality: Natural outcrops between Araguai- na and Filadel¢a in the Maranha‹o Basin, State of Tocantins, NE Brazil
Collection: Museum fu«r Naturkunde Chem- nitz, Germany

Notes on age: Bomfleur_etal-2016 also supports incertae sedis, as there is insufficient evidence to assign the fossil to Osmundales
Collection: Freiberg University of Mining and Technology, Geological Institute, Freiberg, Germany

Notes on affinities: VanUffelen-1991 is not the original; ORIGINAL NOT FOUND: KRAUSEL,R. 1932. Fossile Pflanzen aus dem TertiSr von Siid-Sumatra. Verh. Geol. Mijnbouwk. GenootschapNed. en Kol. Geol. Serie 9: 5-7. Roos, M.C. 1986. Phylogeneticsystematics of the Drynarioidae(Polypodiaceae).Verh. Kon. Ned. Akad. Wetensch. Natuurk. Ser. 2, Vol. 85, Amsterdam.
Notes on age: VanUffelen-1991 mentions an assignment to Drynaria and to Aglaomorpha heraclea; conservative assignment to crown Aglaomorpha

Author: Hernandez-Castillo, Stockey et Rothwell
Full taxon name: Anemia quatsinoensis Hernandez-Castillo, Stockey et Rothwell
Notes on affinities: This fertile material most closely resembles Anemia subgenus Anemiorrhiza (Schizaeaceae)
Type locality: Apple Bay locality, Quatsino Sound, northern Van- couver Island, British Columbia
Collection: University of Alberta Paleobotanical Collections (UAPC-ALTA)

Notes on age: Older age reported by Testo & Sundue (2016), probably in line with that of Anemia_quatsinoensis
Type locality: region between Nova Olinda and Santana do Cariri (CE), Araripe Basin, northeast Brazil

Author: Stockey, Nishida et Rothwell
Full taxon name: Makotopteris princetonensis Stockey, Nishida et Rothwell
Notes on age: The Princeton Group has been dated as middle Eocene based on studies of freshwater fishes and mammals and by K-Ar dates
Type locality: East bank of the Similkameen River, ca. 8.4 km south of Princeton, British Columbia
Collection: University of Alberta Paleobotanical Collections (UAPC-ALTA)

Author: Smith, Stockey, Nishida et Rothwell
Full taxon name: Trawetsia princetonensis Smith, Stockey, Nishida et Rothwell
Notes on age: A Middle Eocene age has been determined based on data from freshwater fish, mammals and K-Ar dating.
Type locality: east bank of the Similkameen River, 8.4 km south of the town of Princeton, British Columbia, Canada
Specimen (Holotype): Holotype. P1247 A, B3, B4, B5, C.

Author: Barrington
Notes on affinities: A placement within the Cibotiaceae is suggested. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004, the fossil nests aligns with extant Cibotiaceae and Metaxyaceae. @Lantz_etal-1999 place it separate to living Cibotium barometz, in a clade including Metaxya rostrata.
Notes on age: Terrestrial sedimentary rocks in the region of Medford are all Upper Eocene.
Collection: Paleobotanical Collections of the Botanical Museum, Harvard University

Author: Pinson, Manchester et Sessa
Full taxon name: Culcita emberi Pinson, Manchester et Sessa
Notes on affinities: The oblique, complete annulus surely puts it within the Cyatheales.
Formation: Emerald Creek locality (Univerdity of Idaho P-37)
Collection: Paleobotanical Collection of the Florida Museum of Natural History, University of Florida

Author: (Lesquereux) MacGinitie
Notes on affinities: Affinities with Dryopteris cristata and D. floridana
Notes on age: Radioisotopic age of 34.07–36.7 M (40Ar/39Ar radiometry)
Type locality: Florissant and Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument, Colorado
Collection: US National Museum

Notes on affinities: Charcateristic Cnemidaria-type spore morphology.
Collection: palynological collections at Kent State University

Notes on affinities: Affinities with Cyatheaceae, particularly with the Cyathea and Alsophila, but given classification it is not sensible to place within these particular genera as currently circumscribed.
Notes on age: Age was based on dePorta-1965

Notes on affinities: Affinities with Cyatheaceae, particularly with the Cyathea and Alsophila, but given classification it is not sensible to place within these particular genera as currently circumscribed.
Notes on age: Age was based on dePorta-1965

Author: Graham et Jarzen
Full taxon name: Cyathea sp. indet. Graham et Jarzen
Notes on affinities: Affinities with Cyathea, based on the age and distribution the fossil is considered member of crown Cyathea
Notes on age: Stratigraphic correlations place the formation in the middle Oligocene
Type locality: Localities B and C (Lares and Collazo Quebrada)
Collection: Palynology Laboratory, Kent State University

Notes on affinities: The morphology shows resemblance also the Alsophila.
Collection: palynological collections at Kent State University

Notes on affinities: The distinctive morphology of the spore closely resembles that observed for neotropical Sphaeropteris by Gastony and Tryon (1976) — which all belong in Cyathea and are distinct from the S. horrida group.
Collection: palynological collections at Kent State University

Notes on affinities: Charcateristic Cnemidaria-type spore morphology; based on the age and distribution the fossil is considered member of crown Cyathea
Collection: Palynology Laboratory, Kent State University

Notes on affinities: Most similarity with Sphaeropteris myosuroides and Trichipteris mexicana. The two are synonyms of New World Cyathea.
Specimen (Holotype): Slide 10-1, England Slide finder coordinates C-45

Author: Wilson et Yates
Notes on affinities: The author assigned these fossils to the Dicksoniae (incl. Cibotium, Culcita subgenus Calochlaena, Cystodium, Dicksonia). Thus the assignment to the Dicksoniaceae is not justified. Hence, we conservatively treat the fossil as member of the core tree ferns.
Collection: British Museum (Natural History)

Author: Conran, U.Kaulfuss, Bannister, Mildehall et D.E.Lee
Full taxon name: Davallia walkeri  Conran, U.Kaulfuss, Bannister, Mildehall et D.E.Lee
Notes on affinities: The new fossil is placed in the genus Davallia, due to the presence of at least 3–pinnate fronds with free veins; sub-terminal sori on veinlets with an abaxial extension of the ultimate veinlet along the indusium; elongate indusia attached by the base and sides; stalked sporangia; and annuli straight to curved, interrupted. The spores are ±oblong-reniform, bilateral, with a perispore and numerous, low, rounded verrucae, spreading ±radially from the laesura.
Type locality: locality is registered as I43/f8503 in the New Zealand Fossil Record File administered by the Geological Society of New Zealand and GNS Science
Collection: Geology Museum (OU), University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand

Author: Bertoli-Cunha et Dutra
Full taxon name: Dicksonia sp. indet. Bertoli-Cunha et Dutra
Notes on affinities: The frond morphology and marginal sori points to affinities with the Dicksoniaceae, specially Dicksonia
Notes on age: Radiometric dating suggests an age of 44-47 mya
Collection: Museu de Paleontologia da UNISINOS

Notes on affinities: Leaf morphology aligns this species to living species of Drynaria, more specifically with D. propinqua
Compared to Dicksonia arborescense. Based on the morphology of the exile it compares to either Dicksonia or Calochlaena — figures in Gastony_1981 under Culcita.
Collection: Mining-Geolical Institute of Western Siberia, Academy os Sciences, USSR (?)

Notes on affinities: Based on @Christenhusz_etal-2021
Stratigraphic age: Middle to Upper Jurassic (Callovian to Tithonian)
Notes on age: Combination of characters of subgenera
Type locality: San Agustín Farm, Santa Cruz province, Argentina
Organs: Stems, foliar sheaths, roots, rhizome, branches, apices, strobili
Collection: Museo Padre Jesús Molina, Río Gallegos City, Santa Cruz Province.

Author: Ma, Su et Zhang
Full taxon name: Equisetum cf. oppositum  Ma, Su et Zhang
Notes on affinities: Assigned to subgenus Equisetum based on the morphological similarity, and absence of tubers in subgenus Hippochaete
Notes on age: Combined with plant compres- sions, charophytes, ostracodes, and palynological fossils from the Niubao Formation and overlying Dingqinghu Formation indicate that the age of measured section is the Paleocene-Eocene
Type locality: Nima County, the Tibet Autonomous Region, southwestern China
Collection: School of Earth Science, Lanzhou University

Author: Brown
Notes on affinities: @Christenhusz_etal-2021 assigns this fossil to subgen Hippochaete; agreement with @Elgorriaga_etal-2018
Type locality: NW'/4, Sec. 27, T9S, R18E; 91'/ miles E, 1 mile N of Ashwood, Jefferson Co., Oregon
Collection: University of Montana Paleontological Collectio

Author: Falaschi, Zamuner et Foix
Full taxon name: Equisetites minimus Falaschi, Zamuner et Foix
Notes on affinities: @Christenhusz_etal-2021 assigns this fossil to subgen Paramochaete, but the analyses of @Elgorriaga_etal-2018 place two other species of Equisetites (and other fossils) as crown Equisetum (stem of subgen Equisetum + subgen Hippochaete)
Type locality: Monumento Natural Bosques Petrificados, provincia de Santa Cruz, Argentina
Collection: División Paleobotánica del Museo de Ciencias Na- turales de La Plata

Author: Naugolnykh, Tu, Liu et Jin
Full taxon name: Lygodium sanshuiense Naugolnykh, Tu, Liu et Jin
Notes on affinities: based upon their vegetative morphology, epidermal anatomy and the structure of the conducting tissues
Type locality: Jinfu Road, Sanshui District, Foshan City, Guangdong, China
Collection: Museum of Biology, Sun Yet-sen University, Guangzhou, China

Author: Yang, Wang et Pfefferkorn
Full taxon name: Marattia aganzhenensis Yang, Wang et Pfefferkorn
Notes on affinities: The affinities are confirmed by the phylogenetic analysis of @Rothwell_etal-2018, placing it within crown Marattiaceae
Collection: College of Earth and Environmental Sciences, Lanzhou University

Notes on affinities: Based on discussion of affinities, probably placed above Danaea
Type locality: Rotch Dome, Byers Peninsula, South Shetland Islands
Specimen (Holotype): BA Pb 14,985 (Microscope slides BA Pb Pm 610, 625–628)
Collection: Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales “Bernardino R. Rivadavia”, División Paleobotánica

Author: H.Schneid., Heinrichs et A.R.Schmidt
Full taxon name: Pleopeltis dominicensis H.Schneid., Heinrichs et A.R.Schmidt
Notes on affinities: The relationships of the fossil were explored by: (1) comparing morphological similarities with extant taxa; (2) identifying apomorphic character states by reconstructing the evolution of characters preserved in the fossil; and (3) analy- ses employing phylomorphospace reconstruction.
Notes on age: The age of the Dominican amber deposit has been recently constrained from the stratigraphic age estimation of Burdigalian (15.8–20.3 Mya) to approximately 16 Ma
Collection: Dominican amber collection of the American Museum of Natural History, New York

Notes on affinities: Assignment to subgenus Meniscium, but not sure due to taxonomy of the group
Formation: La Paila Fm and La Pobreza Fm, Valle Group
Collection: Fossil Collection of the Caldas University (CAL) and Colombian Geological Institute (INGEOMINAS)

Author: Bonde et Kumaran
Notes on affinities: Characters of the fossil suggest its undoubted affinity with Acrostichum
Type locality: Nawargaon, District Wardha, Ma- harashtra, India, 21‡01PN, 78‡35PE
Collection: Department of Botany, Agharkar Research Institute, Pune, India

Author: Beauchamp, Lemoigne et Petrescu
Full taxon name: Acrostichum palaeoaureum Beauchamp, Lemoigne et Petrescu
Notes on age: Ash-IV is a 3–7-m-thick, basin-wide unit that occurs stratigraphically above the basalt and is dated by 40Ar/39Ar at 27:36 6 0:11 Ma
Type locality: Chilga, ca. 60 km west-southwest of Gondar on the northwestern Ethiopian Plateau, along the slopes of the Magargaria River (12°30931.30N, 37°6957.30E) and along the Guang River (12°30943.440N, 37°7924.180E)
Formation: Volcanic ash deposits within Ash-IV in the Guang River section and lignitic deposits within Ash- IV in the Magargaria River
Specimen (Holotype): CH-55 6 (fig. 2A), CH-55 4 (fig. 2B), CH-55 2 (fig. 2C), CH-79 21 A (fig. 2D), CH-79 21 B (fig. 2E), and CH-79 21 A-B #1 (fig. 2F–2H)
Collection: National Museum of Ethiopia, Addis Abada

Author: Xu et Jin
Notes on affinities: The frond shape, the rachis structure and the venation characteristic of ultimate segment in fossil specimens mostly resemble the extant species of Asplenium
Collection: Museum of Biology, Sun Yet-sen University, Guangzhou, China

Author: (Dijkstra) Potonié
Notes on affinities: Re-analysis of @Dijkstra-1949 collection, the spore-wall morphology confirm the evolutionary links to several taxa within the Salviniales and other fossils possibly related to the group.
Notes on age: Originally dated as (middle) Senonian, the more precise determination of Santonian to possibly early Campanian is now generally accepted
Specimen (Holotype): SEM micrographs depicted in figure (all from Dijkstra's slide collection)
Collection: Not provided

Author: Ogura
Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Cibotiaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004, the fossil nests aligns with extant Cibotiaceae and Metaxyaceae. @Lantz_etal-1999 place it separate to living Cibotium barometz, in a clade including Metaxya rostrata. A placement in the Cibotium/Metaxya clade is thus suggested.
Collection: Geological Institute of Hokkaido Imperial University

Author: Menendez
Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Cibotiaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004, the fossil nests with extant Cibotiaceae and Metaxyaceae. @Lantz_etal-1999 place it separate to living Cibotium barometz, in a clade including Metaxya rostrata. A placement in the Cibotium/Metaxya clade is thus suggested, with further assignment to Cibotium following @Gould-1971
Type locality: Catamaran Road, 2.33 km south of the junction with the Forestry road to Toms Bottom
Collection: University of Tasmania, department of Geology

Notes on affinities: Affinities with the Cyatheaceae, but note the broad circumscription of the family. @Lantz_etal-1999 place it separate to living Cibotium barometz, in a clade including Metaxya rostrata.
Collection: Brigham Young University

Notes on affinities: Based on the spore morphology (Plate V, fig. 10), with three equatorial pores that are characteristic of some Cyathea (i.e., Cnemidaria-type spores); directly compared to Hemitelia karsteniana. There are some doubts on the “holotype” referred in the original (see compilers preface of @Traverse_Ames-1979). In this case, the specimen number is the same for Dicksonia dubia and Hemitelia mirabilis. Possibly, this reflects the presence of multiple spores in the same sample.
Type locality: Southern Urals, left bank of the Ayat settlement, against the settlement of Novonikolayevskogo
Collection: Mining-Geolical Institute of Western Siberia, Academy os Sciences, USSR (?)

Notes on affinities: Synonym with K scutatus. Characteristic Cnemidaria-type spore morphology.
Collection: Michigan State University Herbarium

Notes on affinities: cf. Mohr_Lazarus-1994; originally described as Hemitelia separata (cf. @Traverse_Ames-1979)
Type locality: Teulches Creek, 50 mk above its mouth
Collection: Mining-Geolical Institute of Western Siberia, Academy os Sciences, USSR (?)

Notes on affinities: Assigned to Cyathea based on spore morphology, with the distinctive Cnemidaria-type features; characters are also present in Cyathea decurrens, sister to the Neotropical clade of Cyathea.
Notes on age: The fossil assemblage found in these strata can be assigned to the Chiasmolithus gigas Subzone of the Nanotetrina quadrata Zone, which equals late early to mid Middle Eocene
Formation: Chiasmolithus gigas subzone and Nannotetrina quadrata zone
Specimen (Holotype): IO1578-59 (piston core), 26-28 cm slide B, 123-125 cm slide D
Collection: Antarctic Research Facility

Author: (Ogura) Ogura
Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Cyatheaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil can be attributed to stem Cyatheaceae
Collection: University Museum of the University of Tokyo

Author: Menendez
Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Cyatheaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil nests well within the Cyatheaceae, but resolution does not allow for further detail.
Type locality: 8 km from Aluminé City, Neuquen Province
Collection: Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales “Bernardino R. Rivadavia”, División Paleobotánica
University of Alberta Paleobotanical Collections (UAPC-ALTA)

Notes on affinities: Affinities with Cyatheaceae genera according to Villar de Soane (1999). The oblique uninterrupted annulus puts it within the tree ferns, whereas  it shares the median position of the sori with the Cyatheaceae. The name was changed to Cyathea cyathifolia by Villar de Soane (1999) (from Cladophlebis cyathifolia).
Specimen (Holotype): BAPb 11479; BA Pb Pm 5135 coord: 34/95, BA Pb MEB 60
Collection: Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales “Bernardino R. Rivadavia”, División Paleobotánica

Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Cyatheaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil can be attributed to stem Cyatheaceae.
Collection: University Museum of the University of Tokyo

Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Cyatheaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil can be attributed to stem Cyatheaceae.
Collection: Laboratory of Phylogenetic Botany, Faculty of Science, Chiba University

Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Cyatheaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil can be attributed to stem Cyatheaceae.
Collection: University Museum of the University of Tokyo

Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Cyatheaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil can be attributed to stem Cyatheaceae.
Collection: National Science Museum Tokyo; Laboratory of Phylogenetic Botany, Faculty of Sciences, Chiba University

Author: Bancroft
Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Cyatheaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil nests well within the Cyatheaceae, but resolution does not allow for further detail.
Collection: British Museum (Natural History)

Notes on affinities: Affinities with the Cyatheaceae, but no further assignment to genera is possible. A phylogenetic analyses might be possible based on the table of characters presented in Vera & Cesari 2018.
Notes on age: A phylogenetic analyses might be possible based on the table of characters presented in Vera & Cesari 2018.
Type locality: Henan Village, Keshan County, Wiqihar City
Collection: Geological Museum of China

Author: (Oldham and Morris) Halle
Collection: The Natural History Museum, London

Notes on affinities: cf. Archangelsky & Llorens 2003
Notes on age: Oblique annulus

Author: Vera
Notes on affinities: Affinities with Thyrsopteridaceae and the Cyatheaceae. Thus I treat the fossil as Cyatheales. A phylogenetic analyses might be possible based on the table of characters presented in Vera & Cesari 2018. Also a useful table in Vera & Herbst (2015)
Type locality: Rotch Dome, Byers Peninsula, South Shetland Islands
Collection: Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales “Bernardino R. Rivadavia”, División Paleobotánica

Author: Naugolnykh, Wang, Han et Jin
Full taxon name: Cyclosorus scutum Naugolnykh, Wang, Han et Jin
Notes on affinities: the material studied can be clas- sified into Cyclosorus, Thelypteridaceae with certainty, despite the exact attribution of C. scutum on subgeneric level remaining unclear.
Notes on age: The fossils of Cyclosorus, described here, were collected from the coal- bearing deposits of the Changchang Formation assigned to an Eocene age according to the published paleobotanical (megafossil) and palynological data.
Type locality: Jiazi Town, the City of Qiongshan, northeastern part of the Hainan Island, China
Organs: Sterile and fertile fronds, sporangia, spores
Collection: Museum of Biology, Sun Yet-sen University, Guangzhou, China

Author: Regalado, A.R.Schmidt, H.Schneid., Krings et Heinrichs
Full taxon name: Cystodium sorbifolioides Regalado, A.R.Schmidt, H.Schneid., Krings et Heinrichs
Notes on age: Burmese amber (Burmite), Earliest Upper Cretaceous, earliest Cenomanian, absolute age 98.79 ± 0.62 million years ago established by U-Pb dating of zircons from the rind of the unprocessed amber
Type locality: Amber mines near Tanai, Ledo Road, 105 km northwest of Myitkyina, Kachin State, Myanmar
Collection: Geoscientific Collections of the University of Göttingen

Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Dicksoniaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil nests well within the Dicksoniaceae, sister to Lophosoria (but resolution)
Collection: California Academy of Sciences

Notes on age: Stratigraphic correlation with the Xiaolongtan Fm., which recent palaeomagnetic dating has limited its age to be within ca. 14.1–10 Ma (Li et al. 2015b; Zhang et al. 2019).
Type locality: Bangmai Village (N 23°54′, E 100°0′), Lincang, Yunnan, China
Collection: Institute of Palaeontology and Stratigraphy, Lanzhou University

Author: Lóriga, A.R.Schmidt, R.C.Moran, K.Feldberg, H.Schneid. et Heinrichs
Full taxon name: Elaphoglossum miocenicum Lóriga, A.R.Schmidt, R.C.Moran, K.Feldberg, H.Schneid. et Heinrichs
Notes on age: The amber has been dated as early Miocene, 20 to 15 Myr old, and was exuded by resin-bearing species of Hymenaea in the Fabaceae.
Collection: amber collection of the U. S. National Museum of Natural History at the Smithsonian Institution

Author: Bateman
Notes on affinities: Phylogenetic analyses of @Elgorriaga_etal-2018 place this fossil as sister to extant Equisetaceae
Notes on age: The Oxroad Bay sequence has been dated as late Tournaisian. However, based on @Scott_Galtier-1996, the Tournaisian age of these localities might be revised to Visean or even Late Visean.
Specimen (Holotype): Syntypes: OBC001d1B, OBC061b1T, OBC084dB, OBC084eT, OBC084gB
Collection: British Museum (Natural History)

Notes on affinities: No reference given in Testo & Sundue (2016) to 'Archaeocalamites'. From Mamay_Bateman-1991 it appears that the genus goes back to the lower Carboniferous
Notes on age: Stratigraphic correlations; the Leonard series are roughly Kungurian–Artinskian in age, further bracketing the age of the fossil.
Type locality: south of Fuldain Baylor County, north-centralTexas
Collection: US National Museum

Author: Cesari et Perez Loinaza
Full taxon name: Gondwanites subtilis Cesari et Perez Loinaza
Notes on affinities: Assigned to extinct Notocalamitaceae
Notes on age: This is a slightly younger age as the 'Archaeocalamites' used by  Testo & Sundue (2016)
Type locality: Un Salto Creek and Sierra de Barreal, San Juan Province
Collection: Paleobotany Collection at the Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales “Bernardino Rivadavia”

Author: Herendeen et J.Skog
Notes on affinities: Cladistic analysis places the fossil sister to Gleichenia glauca, both clearly segregated from other genera; however, a single extant species of Gleichenia does not allow to ascertain whether the fossil lays within the crown group. Conservatively placing the fossil as stem
Collection: paleobotanical collections of the Department of Geology, The Field Museum (PP)

Author: Yao et Taylor
Notes on age: Equivalent to Guadalupian sediments of North America
Type locality: Funiushan Coal Mine, between Nan- jing and Zhenjiang, approximately 20 km from Zhenjiang, Jiangsu Province
Collection: Palaeobotany Collection, Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Academia Sinica, Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China

Type locality: Baiyingbaoligao Village of Daiqintala Town, Horqin Right Wing Middle Banner, Inner Mongolia
Collection: Shenyang Institute of Geology and Mineral Resources, Shenyang

Author: Xu et Zhou
Notes on age: According to a recent magnetostratigraphic study, the sedimentary succession was assigned to Middle Miocene (15.2–16.5 Ma).
Type locality: Dashidong village, the Wenshan Basin, southeastern Yunnan, China
Collection: Herbarium of Kunming Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences (KUN)

Author: Axsmith, Krings et Taylor
Full taxon name: Hopetedia praetermissa Axsmith, Krings et Taylor
Notes on affinities: We have no evidence to assign it to the crown, but the authors here state there is insufficient evidence to link the fossil to any extant lineage
Notes on age: The middle portion of the Pekin Formation exposed in the Boren Clay Company pit near Gulf (North Carolina, USA). This portion of the Pekin Formation has been dated as late Carnian and is the source of a well-known Upper Triassic flora.
Type locality: Boren Clay Company Pit near Gulf, North Carolina US
Collection: paleobotanical collection of the University of Kansas, Lawrence

Author: Herrera, R.C.Moran, Shi, Ichinnorov, Takahashi, Crane et Herendeen
Full taxon name: Hymenophyllum iwatsukii Herrera, R.C.Moran, Shi, Ichinnorov, Takahashi, Crane et Herendeen
Notes on affinities: Assigned to the Hymnophyllaceae based on a combination of vegetative and reproductive characters
Notes on age: Aptian-Albian age based on stratigraphic correlations and palynomorphs recovered from the plant localities
Type locality: Tevshiin Govi (45°58′54′′ N, 106°07′12′′ E) and Tugrug (46°53′05′′ N, 108°03′38′′ E) coal mines, central Mongolia
Collection: Paleobotanical Collections, Department of Geology, The Field Museum, Chicago, Illinois, USA

Author: Regalado, A.R.Schmidt, Müller, Kobbert, H.Schneid. et Heinrichs
Full taxon name: Lindsaeaceae gen. et. sp. indet. Regalado, A.R.Schmidt, Müller, Kobbert, H.Schneid. et Heinrichs
Notes on age: Burmese amber (Burmite), Earliest Upper Cretaceous, earliest Cenomanian, absolute age 98.79 ± 0.62 million years ago established by U-Pb dating of zircons from the rind of the unprocessed amber
Type locality: Amber mines near Tanai, Ledo Road, 105 km northwest of Myitkyina, Kachin State, Myanmar
Collection: Geoscientific Collections of the Georg August University Go€ttingen

Author: Cantrill
Notes on affinities: Affinities with the Lophosoriaceae, based on the distinctive spores of Cyatheacidites annulatus. The spores from Lophosoria cupulatus arebest placed within C. annulatus Cookson ex Potonie, and confirm placement within the Lophosoriaceae.
Collection: British Antarctic Survey collections

Notes on affinities: The morphology fits perfectly with extant Lophosoria
Organs: Fertile foliage, with sporangia and spores
Collection: Not provided

Notes on affinities: This records is based on the Dettmann’s description of the Cookson’s type material from Kerguelen.
Collection: British Australian New Zealand An arctic Research Expedition, 1929-1931 (BANZARE) Collection (Museum of Victoria)

Notes on affinities: There are some doubts on the “holotype” referred in the original (see compilers preface of Traverse_Ames-1979). In this case, the specimen number is the same for Lophosoria falsa and Alsophila arctua. Possibly, this reflects the presence of multiple spores in the same sample.
Type locality: The northern shore of the Aral Sea, in the south of the Kulandy Peninsula
Specimen (Holotype): sl. 1, arr. 12, ИГН АН СССР no. 3527/26
Collection: Mining-Geolical Institute of Western Siberia, Academy os Sciences, USSR (?)

Notes on affinities: Assigned to the Lophosoriaceae.
Collection: Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales “Bernardino R. Rivadavia”, División Paleobotánica

Author: J.Skog
Notes on affinities: On the basis of scletoric outer cortex and the characteristic hairs on the epidermis, the fossil is described as a new genus in the Losxomataceae
Notes on age: Preliminary examination of pollen preparation of the fossil-bearing bed is consistent with its placement in Zone I, which is probably Aptian in Age.
Collection: Paleobotany  Collections, US National Museum of Natural History

Author: Pomel
Notes on affinities: Comparing the Jurassic Klukia exilis and Stachypteris spicans spores with those recent spores, one may say that they are similar but not strictly comparable, especially their greatly reduced proximal sculpture has not been seen in the Recent spores. Within the Schizaeaceae, however, they certainly resemble most closely those reticulate Lygodium spores (@vanKonijnenburg-1989); therefore these may mark the split between Lygodium and the Anemia/Schizaea clade
Type locality: Marske Quarry, Hasty Bank and Whitby, Yorkshire
Organs: Sterile and fertile fronds, sporangia, spores
Collection: British Museum (Natural History)

Notes on affinities: Phylogenetic analyses placing the fossil as sister to Lygodium (but only one species included);  so conservatively placing as stem Lygodium
Notes on age: The sediments have been dated as Turonian in age
Type locality: Old Crossman Clay Pit, Sayreville, NJ
Formation: South Amboy Fure Clay, Raritan Fm
Collection: Paleobotany Collection (CUPC) of the L. H. Bailey Hortorium

Notes on age: tratigraphically, the coal balls were reported as occurring in a coal seam equivalent to either the Pittsburgh (No. 8) or Redstone (No. 8A) Coals of the Monongahela Series, and are therefore Late Pennsylvanian in age (Sturgeon, 1958)
Specimen (Holotype): Fig. 2 on U.I.C.C. slide #6691 from O.S.U. c.b. #6045
Collection: Paleobotanical Collections, Univ. Illinois at Chicago Circle

Notes on affinities: The assignment is confirmed by the phylogenetic analysis of Rothwell_etal-2018, placing as a stem member of Marattiaceae
Notes on age: Presently, how- ever, the Hsiangchi Formation is generally regarded as Early Jurassic based on various palaeontological evidences, such as plant megafossils, spores–pollen, bivalves and megaspores (Wu et al., 1980; Li and Shang, 1980; Meng, 1987; Meng and Zhang, 1987; Zhang and Zhang, 1987; Yang and Sun, 1987).
Type locality: Xiangxi Town, Zigui County, Hubei Province, China.
Collection: Palaeobotanical Collection of NIGPAS, Nanjing, China

Notes on age: Palaeontological and Sr-isotope data suggest a Coniacian age for the formation (e.g. McArthur et al. 2000, Riding and Crame 2002, Crame et al. 2006)
Specimen (Holotype): H o l o t y p e: CGS No. AN 491
Collection: Czeck Geological Survey and Instituto Antártico Argentino

Notes on affinities: Phylogenetic analysis of Rothwell_etal-2018
Stratigraphic age: late Early (Toarcian) to early Middle Jurassic (Aalenian)
Type locality: Cerro Bayo locality, NW Chubut Province, Argentina.
Collection: Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales “Bernardino R. Rivadavia”, División Paleobotánica

Author: Taylor
Notes on affinities: The affinities are confirmed by the phylogenetic analysis of @Rothwell_etal-2018, placing it as stem Marattiaceae
Formation: Francis Creek Shale, Carbondale Fm, Kewanee group
Collection: Peabody Museum of Natural History, Yale University, Paleobotanical collections

Author: Yamada et Kato
Notes on affinities: Phylogenetic analyses place is as stem relative, sister to extant Marsileaceae; although there is low support (BP = 68) for this position, rendering the possibility of the fossil representing a crown member of Salviniales.
Type locality: Locality 102 on Nakao Forestry Road, Shimonoseki, Yamaguchi Prefecture
Collection: National Science Museum Tokyo

Organs: whole plant with rhizome and leaves
Collection: Florida Museum of Natural History

Author: Klavins, Taylor et Taylor
Full taxon name: Tomaniopteris katonii Klavins, Taylor et Taylor
Notes on affinities: combination of characters that affiliates them with the Matoniaceae
Notes on age: The peat occurs in carbonaceous mudstones of the upper Fremouw Formation, which is early Middle Triassic in age based on palynology and vertebrates
Type locality: Fremouw Peak, Queen Alexandra Range, central Transantarctic Mountains
Specimen (Holotype): Holotype, 49 slides of specimen 11248A, slide Nos. 20461–20465, 20466–20510
Collection: Division of Paleobotany of the Natural History Museum and Biodiversity Research Center, University of Kansas

Notes on affinities: K. alata exhibits vegetative and reproductive characters shared with both extant Matoniaceae genera
Type locality: Puesto Galpçon locality, and Curvon de Bagual locality
Specimen (Holotype): Specimen NRMS116525A (Halle, 1913, plate 1, fig.1) and its counterpart NRMS116525B
Collection: Swedish Museum of Natural History, Stockholm

Author: H.Schneid., A.R.Schmidt et Heinrichs
Full taxon name: Krameropteris resinatus H.Schneid., A.R.Schmidt et Heinrichs
Notes on affinities: Monachosorum species resemble the fossil in the formation of trilete spores, presence of exindusiate sori and a simultaneous maturity of sporangia. Given the uncertainty of character state evolution, the fossil may not be a member of the stem of Monachosorum as considered here but actually better placed at the branch leading to the split between Monachosorum and the HYP-clade. However, this appears to be less likely given the character state reconstructions obtained.
Notes on age: Biostratigraphic studies suggested a late Albian age of the amber- bearing sediment, hence the inclusions have a late Early Cretaceous age, with a minimum age of 98 million years (earliest Cenomanian, early Late Cretaceous) that is based on recent U-Pb dating of zircons.
Type locality: Amber mines near Tanai, about 105 km north of Myitkyina in Kachin State
Collection: American Museum of Natural History, New York

Author: L.
Type locality: Munce's Hill, near Red Deer, Alberta
Organs: Sterile and fertile fronds, sporangia, spores
Collection: University of Alberta Paleobotanical Collections (U.A.P.C.)

Author: Chlonova
Notes on affinities: The spore bears a resemblance to modern Ophioglossum lusitanicum and Ophioglossum falcatum, differs from them in larger sizes and in the presence of a smooth area around the three-beam slit
Type locality: Chulym, near the village of Suchkovo and 500 m from the village of Simonovo, right bank of the river Kemr, 2 km below the mouth
Collection: Geological Institute of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR

Author: (Maljavkina) Chlonova
Notes on affinities: The surface of the exine, covered with small papillae, makes it possible to compare this spore with the spores of modern ferns Osmunda regalis' and Osmunda Claytoniana (collection of reference spore preparations) and with Osmunda triassica. But none of these species can be identified with our specimens.
Type locality: Chulym, near the village of Suchkovo and 500 m from the village of Simonovo, right bank of the river Kemr, 2 km below the mouth
Collection: Geological Institute of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR

Author: (Zhang et Zheng) Tidwell
Type locality: Baiyingbaoligao Village of Daiqintala Town, Horqin Right Wing Middle Banner, Inner Mongolia
Collection: Shenyang Institute of Geology and Mineral Resources, Shenyang

Author: Kvacek
Notes on affinities: The fossils are compared to Polypodium, with reference to P. vulgare complex. Our tree rendered a paraphyletic Polypodium by monotypic Pleurosoriopsis. Two options: assign the fossil to stem Polypodium ss (excluding Pleurosoriopsis and P. pellucidum) or to crown Polypodium sl (including Pleurosoriopsis and P. pellucidum). As the fossil clearly aligns with Polypodium, we here chose to calibrate crown Polypodium sl.
Notes on age: Radiometric dating of the sodalite trachyte which penetrated into the sediments putas an age of 20-30 Mya for the fossiliferous shale
Formation: Usti Formation of the Ceske stredohori Mountains
Collection: National Museum, Praha

Notes on age: Biostratigraphic correlation places these outcrops in the Eutaw Formation or its nonmarine equivalent on the Gulf Coastal Plain
Type locality: Upatoi Creek, Chattahoochee County, Georgia, U.S.A
Collection: paleobotanical collections of the Field Museum, Chicago

Type locality: Cerro Bosta, Bajada del Diablo area, north-central Chubut Province, Patagonia, Argentina

Author: (Phillips) Raciborski
Notes on affinities: Comparing the Jurassic Klukia exilis and Stachypteris spicans spores with those recent spores, one may say that they are similar but not strictly comparable, especially their greatly reduced proximal sculpture has not been seen in the Recent spores. Within the Schizaeaceae, however, they certainly resemble most closely those reticulate Lygodium spores (@vanKonijnenburg-1989); therefore these may mark the split between Lygodium and the Anemia/Schizaea clade
Organs: Sterile and fertile fronds, sporangia, spores
Collection: British Museum (Natural History) and Sedgwick Museum, Cambridge

Type locality: Roseberry Topping; Beast Cliff, nr. Petard Point; Farndale, Hillhouse Nab
Formation: Lower and Middle Deltaic Series, Yorkshire flora
Collection: British Museum (Natural History)

Type locality: Old Crossman Clay Pit, Sayreville, NJ
Collection: Paleobotany Collection of the L.H. Bailey Hortorium

Type locality: Munce’s Hill, a roadcut 3 km northeast of Can- yonSkiQuarry(NW1/4sect.S34,T38,R26,W4)incen- tral Alberta, Canada
Collection: University of Alberta Paleobotanical Collections (UAPC-ALTA)

Author: Regalado, H.Schneid., M.Krings et Heinrichs
Full taxon name: Holttumopteris burmensis Regalado, H.Schneid., M.Krings et Heinrichs
Notes on affinities: Based on the character state reconstruction, fossil is assigned to the eupolypod ferns, perhaps representing a stem group element of Thelypteridaceae.
Type locality: Amber mines near Tanai, Ledo Road, 105 km northwest of Myitkyina, Kachin State, Myanmar
Collection: Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology

Author: Tidwell, Nishida et Webster
Full taxon name: Oguracaulis banksii Tidwell, Nishida et Webster
Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Thyrsopteridaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil nests is sister to extant Thyrsopteris.
Collection: Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery; Brigham Young University (paratype)

Author: Arnold
Notes on affinities: Affinities within the Thyrsopteridaceae. According to @Stockey_Rothwell-2004 and @Lantz_etal-1999, the fossil nests is sister to extant Thyrsopteris.
Type locality: 10 miles North of Roma, Starr Cty, Texas
Collection: University of Michigan Collection

Notes on affinities: Comparison of characters with several genera in the Cyatheales; but closer resemblance to Thyrsopteris
Notes on age: Affinities with Thyrsopteris
Collection: Laboratory of Phylogenetic Botany, Chiba University

Author: Chlonova
Notes on affinities: This species is similar to modern spores of Trichomanes alatum and Trichomanes angustatum, but differs from the former in the character of the exine surface (in Trichomanes alatum it is finely prickly), from the latter it is more large in size. Trichomanes s.s. is used in PPGI, but Trichomanes s.l. was in use at the time of the publication of the fossil. Trichomanes s.l. in PPGI corresponds to subfamily Trichomanoideae.
Type locality: Chulym, near the village of Suchkovo and 500 m from the village of Simonovo, right bank of the river Kemr, 2 km below the mouth
Collection: Geological Institute of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR

Type locality: Bear Den Member at Iocs. 14066c and 14121

Specimen (Holotype): Holotype: Figured here (Fig. 2A and C); No. CCJ 171A (part) and CCJ 171B (counterpart)
Collection: Museum of Biology, Sun Yet-sen University, Guangzhou, China

Type locality: Wuda Coal District near the city of Wuda in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region of North China
Collection: Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences.

Type locality: East bank of the Similkameen River, ca. 8.4 km south of Princeton, British Columbia

Author: Karafit et Stockey
Notes on affinities: Schizaceae sensu lato, which include Lygodium, Anemia, and Schizea; but directly compared to Anemia, thus assignment to Schizeaceae ss
Notes on age: the Eden Main localities have been dated as upper Turonian to lower Coniacian using mollusc, index fossils
Collection: University of Alberta Paleobotanical Collections (UAPC-ALTA)

Author: Kvacek
Formation: Děčín Formation of the České středohoří Mts.
Collection: Paleontological department of the National Museum in Prague

Author: Nagalingum et Cantrill
Notes on affinities: Assigned to Gleicheniaceae based on the presence of the syna- pomorphy of a resting bud surrounding by branches
Notes on age: These fluvial strata have been assigned a Late Albian age on the basis of bracketing molluscan faunas (105 Ma).
Formation: Triton Point Formation, Fossil Bluff Group
Collection: British Antarctic Survey

Author: Nagalingum et Cantrill
Notes on affinities: Assigned to Matoniaceae based on the presence of circular to oval sori with a peltate indusium.
Notes on age: These fluvial strata have been assigned a Late Albian age on the basis of bracketing molluscan faunas (105 Ma).
Formation: Triton Point Formation, Fossil Bluff Group
Organs: Sterile and fertile fronds, sporangia, spores
Collection: British Antarctic Survey

Author: Regalado, A.R.Schmidt, M.Krings et H.Schneid.
Full taxon name: Heinrichsia cheilanthoides Regalado, A.R.Schmidt, M.Krings et H.Schneid.
Notes on affinities: The fossil was assigned to the order Polypodiales based on the presence of a vertical annulus interrupted by the sporangium stalk. The presence of marginal sori protected by pseudoindusia therefore is strong support of the affinities of the fossil to the Pteridaceae.
Notes on age: Biostratigraphic studies (Cruickshank & Ko, 2003) and U‐Pb dating of zircons indicate a late Albian to earliest Cenomanian age of the Burmese amber, with a minimum age of 98 Ma.
Type locality: Amber mines near Tanai, Ledo Road, 105 km northwest of Myitkyina, Kachin State
Collection: Collections of the Geoscience Centre (GZG) at the University of Göttingen

Notes on affinities: The small size, branching style of the leaves, and characteristics of the sori and spores indicate that these fossils belong to the family Hymenophyllaceae. Of the 34 extant genera of Hymenophyllaceae (Copeland 1938, 1947), the fossils are most similar to Hymenophyllum and Mocodium based on the outline of the sterile frond, but are closer to Gonocormus based on the fertile fronds and sorus arrangement.
Collection: Not provided

Author: Chen et Meng
Notes on affinities: The fossil are compared to species of Athyrium sensu stricto (not sensu PPG1). Taken as is to calibrates Athyrium ss.
Notes on age: The age is Aptian-Neocomian based on stratigraphic correlations
Type locality: Fuxin Basin and Tiefa Basin, Liaoning province; Huolinnhe Basin, Inner Mongolia
Formation: Fuxin and Xiaominganbei Formations; Huolinhe Formation
Collection: China University of Geosciences

Notes on affinities: The fossil are compared to species of Athyrium sensu stricto (not sensu PPG1). Taken as is to calibrates Athyrium ss
